Winnipeg, Feb. 3.
Sir Charles Tupper has commenced active canvassing in the North-West Territory, supported by ex-Prime Minister Piper.
The Quebec Government having been defeated, Mercier has assumed control and the Liberal minority, which Radisson will have to face, an adjournment has been made to March 16th.
Mr. Blair addressed a large public meeting in Montreal lately. His name caused some sensation because of his attacks upon Sir John A. Macdonald.
Mr. Donald A. Smith has been appointed to canvass Montreal West in the Conservative interest.

An article in the Berlin Post, generally regarded as a semi-official organ, raising a cry of alarm over war preparations in Europe, has been translated into French and published in the Canadian newspapers.
The article has been very generally condemned.

The Italian army of occupation in the South has almost annihilated by the Austrians.
Dickie, of Garibaldi, will oppose Perley in Eastern Australia in the Reform interest.

Sir Charles Tupper, having become minister-general, and Campbell has retired.
The latter is generally believed to be the incoming Lieutenant-Governor of Ontario.

Van Horne, of the C.P.R., has been appointed Superintendent of the Medicine Hat division.

For several days severe storms have prevailed between Brandon and the mountains, and communication has been interrupted by the regular mail.
A Calgary disaster today.
There is a complete blockade on the railway, both east and west.
A train that left Edmonton on Monday morning reported slack thirty miles east of the point.
Engineers went down from here with a load of coal and returned without delay.
We can get no idea of the condition of the track on the main line, but it is probably seriously blocked.
The weather is intensely cold, and to make matters worse a coal famine prevails.
Efforts are being made to send a relief train eastward, but east and west, freight cannot move on account of the snow blockade."

The North Dufferin election petition has been dismissed.

The aggregate value of improvements in the district during the past year was $81,260.
Not bad.
The improvement for the year previous aggregated $12,455.

The greatest consolation to one growing old is the consciousness of having done what came with age, experience and wisdom.
We are reminded of this fact by the death of Mr. David Murray, a descendant of Detroit, Mich.
They say that while reputation is the best thing and lasts longest, fame in the United States (Millions) of people, gardening both for profit and pleasure, are doing their utmost to satisfy the curiosity and delight in using their skills.
Every one desiring seeds of the highest type and best quality, should secure their Annual.
It is next year on application.

CHIT-CHAT LOCALS
Gathered by our Reporters.
Cold weather.
Snow booming.
W. V. MacLise has left for Ft. S. Croix.
It is expected that Mr. Laird will arrive by the next mail.
T. N. Conner has arrived back from Winnipeg Monday last.
Mr. Letellier, of St. V. de Croix, arrived in town this week.
The annual meeting will take place until Wednesday night, at his present store.
A two-meeting will take place in the Methodist Church, Goddes, on Tuesday evening.

A literary and musical entertainment will take place in St. Paul's church next Friday.

Mr. Mcleod, of the Indian office, has been transferred to Regina, and succeeded at this point by Mr. Van hougen.

We have received a letter from Mr. Christie of Christie's Crossing, in reply to Mr. Molloy's letter, but as the latter is out of the political arena now and the former is not, there is no occasion for further discussion.

The most serious work was the worst and the coldest the most severe that has been experienced on the Saskatchewan for many years.
High winds are now blowing, and the snow is falling off violently.
We trust this unsatisfactory state of the climate is not due to the recent approach of the distinguished P.E. Island snowstorm.

On Friday evening Rev. Dr. Jar din delivered a very interesting and instructive address on "The North-West."
Though the night was exceedingly disagreeable there was quite a large number present.
Rev. Mr. Campbell occupied the chair.
The future treated of the past, present, and future of the North-West of India, but so much time was occupied by space we are unable to give even a summary of it at present.

We have much pleasure in announcing that most of the swiftest skaters in the town, both among the citizens and police, have promised to take part in the ten mile race to be held on Saturday afternoon, on Thursday evening, Feb. 10th.
This being a handicap race in which W. H. Flinn, of the Prince Albert Curling Club, and Mr. Letellier's will make it more interesting.
The race will be repeated on subsequent evenings, and one of the competitors will be chosen to medal two out of three times, such competitor to be selected according to the distance made in the first race.

A ball under the auspices of Kinloch Lodge No. 16, A.F. & A.M., O.R.M., took place at the Queen's Hotel on Wednesday evening.
The weather was cold, and the guests were too few to attend owing to the fact that the mail only arrived late evening and was late.
The halliard ball, which was decorated with flags and Masonic mottoes, under the direction of Mr. Guiltiere.
The dinner was also excellent, Mr. Lapper, who was provided by Mr. Oran, was all that could be desired.
The party broke up about 3 o'clock.
